title: Reduced Bone Mass in Collagen Prolyl 4-Hydroxylase P4ha1+/−; P4ha2−/− Compound Mutant Mice
text: This study demonstrates that compound mutations in collagen prolyl 4-hydroxylase subunits P4ha1 and P4ha2 lead to reduced bone mass in mice. We reveal the critical role of collagen hydroxylation in maintaining bone homeostasis.

text: 3DMOUSEneST represents a novel volumetric imaging approach for studying embryo-uterine interactions without the need for labeling. This method provides unprecedented insights into decidualization processes and implantation dynamics.

title: MatriCom, a single-cell RNA-sequencing data mining tool to infer cell–extracellular matrix interactions
text: We present MatriCom, a computational tool designed to mine single-cell RNA sequencing data to identify and analyze cell-extracellular matrix (ECM) interactions. This tool enables researchers to systematically explore ECM-ECM and cell-ECM communication systems at single-cell resolution.

title: Analysis of extracellular matrix network dynamics in cancer using the MatriNet database
text: The extracellular matrix (ECM) undergoes extensive remodeling during cancer progression. We present MatriNet, a comprehensive database that captures ECM network dynamics across multiple cancer types. Our analysis reveals distinct ECM signatures associated with tumor progression and metastasis.

title: Valerio Izzi, PhD
text:
Valerio Izzi is an Associate Professor of Bioinformatics at the University of Oulu, Finland. He leads the Izzi Group on Bioinformatics and Data Analysis within the Faculty of Biochemistry and Molecular Medicine. His research focuses on understanding the regulation of extracellular matrix (ECM) production in cancer and its effects on the tumor microenvironment, hematopoiesis, and immunity.
Dr. Izzi established his independent research group in 2020 after being tenured in the Profi-5 call at the University of Oulu. His lab has become internationally recognized for developing computational tools and databases for matrisome analysis.

Dr. Izzi established his independent research group in 2020 after being tenured in the Profi-5 call at the University of Oulu. His lab has become internationally recognized for developing computational tools and databases for matrisome analysis.

title: Rijuta Lamba
text:
Biography
I am a Doctoral Student in Bioinformatics in the Izzi Group since April 2021.
I completed my Bachelors’ degree in Biological Sciences from the University of Florence, Italy. During my stay in Florence, I interned at the Institute of Ecosystem Studies of the National Council of Research in Florence for my thesis and worked on understanding the diversity and phylogeny of Nostoc cf communales(cyanobacteria) from Greenland. My internship gave me the first insight into the world of computational biology, it ensnared my curiosity and propelled me to go on and get my Masters’ degree in Bioinformatics from the University of Bologna, Italy. I carried out at my Masters’ thesis work as an Erasmus scholar at the University of Ghent, Belgium. During my Masters’, I found myself enchanted by the world of Systems and In-Silico Biology and the entire framework of Machine Learning. I fell in love with this mathematical framework to understand biological systems, that allows us to decode seemingly intractable biological mysteries and I am particularly interested in using this framework for modelling the biology of disease, more specifically, cancer.
Currently, I am exploring the matrisome-cancer interface to understand the role that matrisome mutations may play in defining the landscape of the Tumor Microenvironment using a wide variety of computational methods.

This is the Izzi Lab website - an academic research group website for the Izzi Group on Bioinformatics and Data Analysis at the University of Oulu, Finland. The site is built with Quarto and focuses on showcasing research, publications, team members, and news.

Framework: Quarto static site generator
Output: Static HTML in docs/ directory for GitHub Pages hosting
Styling: Bootstrap (Cosmo theme) with custom CSS in styles.css
Icons: Font Awesome 6.5.2 (loaded via CDN)
Project Type: RStudio project (izzilab.Rproj) with optional R integration

People Profiles (people/)

alumni/ - Former members (example_alumni.qmd template)
Frontmatter includes: pagetitle, title, subtitle, sortby, image, toc, about template with links
Uses Quarto’s “trestles” about template for consistent profile layouts

Publications (publications/)

articles/ - Journal articles (27 publications, 2017-2025)
proceedings/ - Conference proceedings (example_conference.qmd template)
Naming convention: authorYEAR.qmd (e.g., lamba2025.qmd, petrov2023.qmd)
Frontmatter: title, author, year, publication, doi, categories
Structure: Abstract, Key Findings, Software Availability (if applicable), Citation

News/Blog Posts (posts/)

Each post in its own folder with index.qmd
Current posts: grant2024/, welcome2025/
Frontmatter: title, author, date, categories, image
Posts can include images and other assets in the same folder

When adding new content, follow these patterns:

New team member:
people/[role]/firstname_lastname.qmd

Add photo to img/ as firstname_lastname.jpg
Use existing profiles as templates
Set sortby for display order

New publication:
publications/articles/authorYEAR.qmd

Follow existing format: Abstract, Key Findings, Citation
Include DOI and categories

New blog post:
posts/descriptive-name/index.qmd

Include date (YYYY-MM-DD format) and categories
Add images to the post folder

Images: Place in img/ and reference with relative paths (e.g., ../../img/filename.jpg)





The site is deployed via GitHub Pages from the docs/ directory
Always run quarto render before committing to ensure docs/ is updated
Use consistent naming: lowercase, underscores for spaces in filenames
Categories in posts and publications help with organization and discovery
The sortby field in people profiles controls display order (lower numbers appear first)
Example/template files exist for URAs, alumni, and conference proceedings

title: TGF-β induces matrisome pathological alterations and EMT in patient-derived prostate cancer tumoroids
text: Using patient-derived prostate cancer tumoroids, we demonstrate how TGF-β signaling drives pathological matrisome alterations and epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT). This study provides insights into tumor microenvironment remodeling in prostate cancer progression.

title: TGF-β induces matrisome pathological alterations and EMT in patient-derived prostate cancer tumoroids
text: Using patient-derived prostate cancer tumoroids, we demonstrate how TGF-β signaling drives pathological matrisome alterations and epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT). This study provides insights into tumor microenvironment remodeling in prostate cancer progression.

title: TGF-β induces matrisome pathological alterations and EMT in patient-derived prostate cancer tumoroids
text:
Key Findings

TGF-β induces comprehensive matrisome remodeling in 3D tumoroids
Identified key ECM proteins driving EMT in prostate cancer
Characterized temporal dynamics of ECM changes during tumor progression
Revealed therapeutic targets within the tumor matrisome

Our findings suggest that targeting TGF-β-induced matrisome alterations could represent a novel therapeutic strategy for aggressive prostate cancer.

title: Izzi Lab
text:
Decoding the Tumor-ECM Dialogue
At the Izzi Lab, our central mission is to understand how tumors communicate with their surrounding environment, the extracellular matrix (ECM). This dynamic dialogue is critical for cancer growth, metastasis, and treatment resistance. We build and apply cutting-edge computational models to listen in on this conversation, aiming to identify novel therapeutic strategies that can disrupt it.
Our research is built on three interconnected pillars:

1. Mapping the Tumor-ECM Ecosystem
Before we can intervene, we must first create a detailed map of the territory. We use multi-omics data (genomics, transcriptomics, proteomics) to build comprehensive models of the tumor microenvironment. Our goal is to uncover the fundamental rules governing how the matrisome—the full collection of ECM proteins—is constructed and remodeled during cancer progression.

Matrisome Profiling: Characterizing the unique ECM signatures of different cancer types and subtypes.
Cell-Matrix Communication: Identifying the signaling pathways that cells use to sense and respond to their ECM.
Spatial & Single-Cell Analysis: Understanding how tumor-ECM interactions vary in space and across individual cells to drive heterogeneity.



2. Building Novel Computational & AI Tools
Standard bioinformatics tools are often insufficient to capture the complexity of the ECM. A core part of our mission is to develop the next generation of software for the research community. We integrate network biology, statistical modeling, and machine learning to create robust, open-source tools that turn raw data into biological insight.

Predictive Modeling: Using AI and deep learning to predict patient outcomes or treatment responses based on ECM signatures.
Algorithm Development: Designing novel graph-based algorithms inspired by complex systems to find key vulnerabilities in the tumor-ECM network.
Flagship Software: Developing and maintaining user-friendly R packages like MatrisomeAnalyzeR and MatriCom for widespread use.



3. Driving Translational Impact & Open Science
Our ultimate goal is to improve patient outcomes. We bridge the gap between computational discovery and clinical application by working closely with oncologists and experimental biologists. By identifying network-based biomarkers and potential drug targets, we aim to contribute directly to the future of cancer therapy.

Therapeutic Target Identification: Pinpointing specific ECM components or regulators that are critical for tumor survival.
Biomarker Discovery: Finding matrisome signatures that can predict metastasis or drug resistance.
Open & Reproducible Science: We are committed to open science, ensuring our code, data, and pipelines are publicly available to accelerate research for everyone.
